title: SSS FINALIST: The Baker and the King
body:
It had been a while since The River King had eaten,
He entered the building, wetting the floor.
The hostess knew just where to seat him,
Old Two-Coats had come back once more.

Tahm Kench gave the menu a peruse,
Although the hostess knew what he'd get,
He did this just to amuse,
"The usual," he ordered, without fret.

"Of course, monsieur," said the bunny,
As she hopped back to the kitchen,
She called, "A Tahm special, nothing funny!"
As she left the chefs nervous and twitchin'

The newest chef didn't quite understand,
Why every other cook started to panic,
Only one cook was not given command,
He asked Akali, "Why so manic?"

"Did nobody tell you who Tahm was?
He's a food critic with a far-reaching tongue.
So get your best flour from the larders,
Lest your baking career be done."

Panth asked "Why don't you prep anything?"
Akali said "I do sashimi.
It's a cannibalism kind of thing,
You wouldn't eat Human Linguine."

Panth's eyes darted around the room,
Including him, the chefs totalled five.
He felt like this was his moment,
He felt like his chance had arrived.

See, Panth always had bakery in his goals
Baking cakes, pies, and sourdoughs everyday,
But here he was stuck making bread rolls,
As his talents simply wasted away.

Everyone else here did as they pleased,
Olaf cutting, Leo searing the meat,
Akali standing there, sushi knife sheathed,
Morgana dousing her cookies with heat.

Panth looked sourly at the new batch of bread rolls,
They were delicious, but boring and bland,
They looked devoid of their souls,
So the Baker hatched a new plan.

He moulded the bread into long sticks,
Kneading them, quietly in a corner, concealed.
He fashioned them into crispy Bread Arrows,
Which he arranged hedgehog style on his shield.

The arrows were crispier, crunchier, warmer,
Than the sad bread rolls lying on the shelf.
He emerged triumphant from his corner,
And went to deliver the bread, himself.

Akali saw him leaving the kitchen,
And said "Dude, turn back round, and quick."
But Panth wasn't going to listen,
And wAkali had been counterpicked.

She dashed as he made a runner,
And blocked her auto with the shield,
He jumped on her quickly to stun her,
And forced the Fist of Shadow to yield.

The rest of the chefs saw the commotion,
And attacked once they realised what they'd seen,
But Pantheon is so totally broken,
That 'QUADRA KILL' showed up on screen.

The Baker finally made it to the table,
Kench eyed his appetiser with concern,
Panth thought the gesture was playful,
But Tahm's eyes grew increasingly stern.

"This ain't my order, Sir Helmet,"
Said the customer, breaking each stick.
"I like my bread smooth, like velvet,
Not rock hard like Malphite's... uh... head?"

Panth saw his creation destroyed,
Tears dripping through his helmet's eyes,
He'd never felt such internal turmoil,
It was only himself that he could depise.

Tahm's eyes widened as he witnessed despair,
Like a child's would on the morning of Christmas,
Such raw sadness, to Tahm, was rare,
And it smelt, oh, so wonderfully delicious.

Tahm's jaw opened wide, receptive,
And swallowed Pantheon with haste
If only he'd been more perceptive,
He could've blocked An Acquired Taste

The Master Chef sighed, satisifed,
He'd eaten a meal he enjoyed.
Before he left he remembered "By the by,
Let me know when the chefs are employed."

The hostess took note of the sentiment,
Trying to avoid the fish stench,
And that's why, ladies and gentleman,
Why you should never feed Tahm Kench.

replies.body:
"Why you should never feed Tahm Kench."
Too true.
